results.title: Elizabeth
results.creator_credit: Jill Bilcock, Shekhar Kapur, Tim Bevan, Eric Fellner, Alison Owen and Working Title Films
results.brief_description: Elizabeth begins during the tense period before Elizabeth I became Queen of England. She is a young vivacious girl thrust suddenly into the machiavellian world of politics when she is tried for treason at the age of 21. Surviving this she becomes Queen, and the film charts the beginning of her reign as she struggles to learn the skills of a monarch. Cate Blanchett is amazing as a young woman who slowly casts off her youth and becomes the legendary Virgin Queen that ruled the Elizabethan age. Shekhar Kapur’s film manages to be both entertaining and historically insightful. Lavish costumes and an excellent cast make this compelling viewing. The cast also includes Joseph Fiennes as Elizabeth’s lover Lord Robert Dudley, Richard Attenborough as Sir William Cecil, and Geoffrey Rush as her political adviser Sir Francis Walsingham. (Awards: Cate Blanchett won the 1998 Golden Globe for Best Actress in a Drama, and “Elizabeth” won the 1998 Academy Award for Best Makeup)

results.title: Elements organised: the periodic table
results.creator_credit: David Jackson, Tony Jolly, BBC and Open University
results.brief_description: A series of excellent demonstrations, with graphics, showing how the great variety in the behaviour of the elements can be organised into a systematic structure, the Periodic Table. Please note that there is some background noise on the tape. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Elements of survival. Part 1. Populations
results.creator_credit: Doug Lower and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: First of a two-part series this episode focuses on the population spiral and looks at mankind from pre-history to the present explosion with its doubling of world population about every 35 years. The film looks at the possible consequences of unchecked growth, and the wide gulf between the haves and the have-nots.

results.title: Elementary electricity
results.creator_credit: Roger Brown and National Geographic Society
results.brief_description: This video begins with a look at the discoveries of Benjamin Franklin and other early inventors who investigated electricity. Students also learn how Edison and his team relied on the basic principles of electricity in their quest to create a practical incandescent light. The video introduces the concepts of current, conductivity, circuits and magnetism. It also looks at modern electric power systems and how they are based on many of Edison’s ideas. Narrated by Gene Galusha.

results.title: Elie Wiesel: first person singular [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Robert H Gardner, Public Broadcasting Service (U.S.) and Lives and Legacies Films
results.brief_description: Elie Wiesel is a Nobel Prize-winning author, Holocaust survivor, and human rights activist. Born in the provincial town of Sighet, Romania on September 30, 1928, Wiesel was just fifteen when he, his family and most of the Sighet population were deported to Auschwitz concentration camp in Poland. Of Wiesel’s entire family, only he and his two older sisters survived. In this documentary, made for television, Wiesel is interviewed extensively and discusses his life, experiences of World War II, faith, Jewish background, relationship with his family, in particular his father, and his writings. Actor William Hurt narrates passages from Wiesel’s book ‘Night’, a memoir based on his time spent in Auschwitz as a teenager, decrying the horrors he witnessed first hand. Wiesel also offers observations on such current events as the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks and the Israeli-Palestine war. This documentary utilises black and white photographs of Europe, before and during World War II, and Wiesel’s own photos depicting the stages of his life. With background music by Bach, and a melancholy original score by Leonard Lionnet, this is a thought-provoking and intelligent work.

results.title: Sue Ford Moving Image Collection
results.brief_description:
The Sue Ford Moving Image Collection contains the film and video work of Australian artist Sue Ford (1943–2009). The collection includes complete films made during the 1970s and 1980s, including “Faces”, “Time changes” and “Egami”, as well as an extensive archive of 8mm home movies, documentary footage, offcuts, and process-based experiments.

Sue Ford is one of Australia’s pre-eminent photographers and experimental filmmakers. Establishing her photographic practice in the late 1960s, she was the first woman photographer to hold a solo exhibition at the National Gallery of Victoria in 1974. She was a key figure in Melbourne’s art scene throughout the 1970s, where she was involved with the Women’s Art Group alongside artists such as Bonita Ely and Micky Allan. After a time spent in Sydney where she was involved with the Sydney Filmmakers Cooperative, she became a founding member of the feminist film collective Reel Women in the late 1970s.

Most of her films were created during this period and she continued to make photographic and multimedia work throughout the 1990s and 2000s. Her work is held in the collection of the National Gallery of Victoria, the Art Gallery of New South Wales, the Art Gallery of Western Australia, and the National Gallery of Australia.

The Sue Ford Moving Image Collection has been generously donated to ACMI by the Sue Ford Archive, co-directed by her son, Ben Ford, and friend, Joy Hirst.

results.title: Element 3
results.creator_credit: Jacques Giraldeau, Andre Belleau and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Made in 1965 to support UNESCO’s campaign for water conservation, this film explores the beauty of this so vulnerable resource and shows how quickly it is dwindling through needless waste, especially in countries best endowed with it. In Egypt the film shows how hard it is to come by water, even today when, within sight of laborious water wheels, a great dam rises. But abused or not, water has extraordinary beauty - in the Zuider Zee, the Rhine, the Volga, the Mississippi, the St. Lawrence, and a hundred other streams shown in this film. (Awards: Rome; Toronto; Salerno.)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jacques Giraldeau, Andre Belleau and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Eli, Eli, Lamma Sabachtani?
results.creator_credit: Andre-Marcel Gagnon, Francois Seguillon and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The cry from the Cross echoed in a film parable, told without words, where sculptured figures of the anguished Christ mix with contemporary scenes of city life. Musical accompaniment is a Dies Irae in memory of the victims of Auschwitz. Religious processions suggest man’s spiritual insight; scenes in city parks or streets reflect the bland tolerance of human suffering.

results.title: Elektra: a tragedy in one act
results.brief_description: Clytemnestra, Queen of Thebes, has murdered her husband with the help of her lover Aegisthus. Electra, her daughter, has taken her younger brother Orestes to safety in a foreign country where he is being raised to avenge his father. Whilst the palace residents (including Chrysothemis, Electra’s sister) have come to terms with the new situation, Electra keeps the memory of her father’s murder alive, waiting for the day of retribution. Hugo von Hofmannsthal’s opera is based on Sophocles’s Electra, with music by Richard Strauss magnificently performed by Leonie Rysanek (Elektra), Astrid Varnay (Clytemnestra), Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau (Orestes) and members of the Konzertvereinigung Wiener Staatsopernchor. Karl Bohm conducts the Wiener Philharmoniker. Sung in German. A booklet containing a synopsis is included.

results.title: Election
results.creator_credit: Alexander Payne, Keith Samples, David Gale, Ron Yerxa, Albert Berger, Bona Fide Productions, MTV Films and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Matthew Broderick plays Jim McAllister, a popular and well respected teacher at George Washington Carver High School. Reese Witherspoon is Tracy Flick, A-Grade student and No. 1 candidate for the student body president. Tracy is confident that her campaign for presidency is going smoothly until Mr McAllister decides to disrupt proceedings and introduce opposition to her as yet unchallenged ride to the top. More than a teenage flick, director Alexander Payne has satirized the popular genre to investigate notions of political and moral corruption. In a clever piece of casting, Matthew Broderick exchanges his Ferris Bueller persona for the devoted and concerned teacher who is slightly burned out from years of teaching. Add to this the disillusionment of a dull marriage and the shameful dismissal of McAllister’s best friend and colleague, and the esteemed civic teacher’s sense of democracy is put to the test. Brilliant performances, subtle humour and an excellent screenplay (an Oscar nomination for Payne and co-writer Jim Taylor). Surprisingly, this film was a box office sleeper. Based on the novel by Tom Perrotta.
